content.statement: Morphisms (also called arrows or maps) are the structure-preserving relationships between objects in a category, representing the fundamental way objects relate to each other.

explanation.intuition: If objects are cities, morphisms are the roads connecting them. What makes a category useful isn't the cities themselves, but the network of roads and how they connect. Morphisms capture 'ways to go from A to B' while preserving relevant structure.
explanation.key_insight: Morphisms are more fundamental than objects in category theory. The slogan is 'objects are defined by their relationships' - an object is completely characterized by all morphisms to and from it.
explanation.technical_details: A morphism f from object A to object B, written f: A→B, is an abstract arrow. The collection of all morphisms from A to B is denoted hom(A,B) or C(A,B). Morphisms must be composable and possess identities, but their internal nature is intentionally abstract.

examples.description: In the category Set, morphisms are ordinary functions f: A→B mapping elements of set A to elements of set B
Morphisms are functions that preserve the group operation: f(a·b) = f(a)·f(b)
There exists morphism a→b if and only if a ≤ b in the partial order
